title-group.article-title: Response to: “Cerebellar Infarctions Mimicking Acute Peripheral Vertigo,” from Yeo et al

body.p: We would first like to thank Yeo et al for their interest toward our paper. We greatly appreciated their clarifications that help us to underline that “vertigo is not only labyrinthitis.”1 Their comments are very important to understand how small cerebellar infarctions, especially those that involve the nodule, may occur with the only symptom of “vertigo.” This aspect must help clinicians to understand that the real amount of isolated vascular vertigo, because of its benign prognosis, can be easily underestimated. In most cases, dizziness or vertigo in the emergency department (ED) is due to benign conditions (vestibular neuritis, orthostatic hypotension). On the contrary, a misdiagnosis of acute stroke may result in significant morbidity and mortality. Physicians in the ED should maintain a high level of suspicion for serious causes.2 On the other hand, an overdiagnosis can lead to unnecessary and expensive series of tests. We think that the head-shaking test and head-impulse test can provide useful clinical data, but it is often necessary to consider other parameters, such as cerebrovascular risk factors, heart diseases (atrial fibrillations, malformations), amount of imbalance (patients with cerebellar stroke are unable to stand1), and duration of vertigo. The whole clinical context is the real value in guiding our clinical suspicion toward the possibility of a cerebellar infarction.
